data.source: COVID-19 infection data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC); population data (2018); yearly average temperature and precipitation from meteoblue.com and indexmundi.com; economic openness from the World Bank Databank; democracy index from the Economist Intelligence Unit (UK).
data.wave_or_subset: Cross-country snapshot using total confirmed cases per one million people as of April 3, 2020.
data.notes: Population data year is 2018. Dependent variable constructed as cases per million on 2020-04-03. Variables include temperature, precipitation, openness (trade as % of GDP), democracy index, and population density.

method.description: The study uses cross-country regression analysis to examine how environmental (temperature, precipitation), economic (openness to trade), and social-political (democracy) factors relate to COVID-19 infection rates per million. Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) models are estimated, including versions with lagged infection values to account for autoregressive dynamics. Multicollinearity is addressed by residualizing lagged infection values against other explanatory variables.
steps: Collect cross-country data: COVID-19 confirmed cases (ECDC), population (2018), temperature and precipitation (meteoblue.com and indexmundi.com), openness (World Bank), and democracy index (Economist Intelligence Unit).
Compute the dependent variable as total confirmed COVID-19 cases per one million people on April 3, 2020.
Estimate an OLS regression of cases per million on temperature, precipitation, openness, democracy, and population density.
Diagnose multicollinearity; address it by regressing lagged infection cases on the explanatory variables and using the residuals in further estimation.
Estimate extended models including lagged infection terms (e.g., no lag, lag 1, lag 9) to capture autoregressive effects.
Evaluate model diagnostics (adjusted R², regression standard error, AIC) and check for heteroscedasticity, normality, and autocorrelation.
Refine the model by excluding non-significant variables (precipitation and population density) and report coefficient estimates for significant predictors.
method.models: Classical Linear Regression Model (OLS); autoregressive specifications with lagged dependent variable; residualization to mitigate multicollinearity; Least Squares estimation.
method.outcome_variable: Total confirmed COVID-19 cases per one million people (as of April 3, 2020).
method.independent_variables: Yearly average temperature; yearly average precipitation; openness (international trade as % of GDP); democracy index; population density; lagged infection cases (autoregressive term).
method.control_variables: Precipitation and population density (tested but found not significant and excluded in re-estimation); lagged infection term (residualized) to control for autoregressive effects.

results.summary: Temperature, economic openness, and democracy are significantly associated with COVID-19 cases per million: higher openness and higher democracy correlate with more cases, while higher temperature correlates with fewer cases. Precipitation and population density are not significant and were excluded. Models showed good fit (especially at lower lags), some heteroscedasticity and non-normality, and little autocorrelation.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Coefficient on yearly average temperature (cases per million)
Coefficient on economic openness (trade % of GDP) (cases per million)
Coefficient on democracy index (cases per million)
